trs: Perhaps he will leave us alone; he will not ruin us anymore.’\\
Tomorrow I will go to the market.’\\
He/she will hopefully go.’ (if I have a say in it)\\
You cannot bring it.’\\
He/she should go to the market.’\\
You (plural) should not eat anything.’\\
Far in the future also, might I not go perhaps?’\\
He/she might go.’ (it is up to him whether he goes, and I don’t know what he is thinking)\\
Perhaps his heart will cool, and he might leave behind his anger (lit. his thinking).’\\

Maybe we won’t be destroyed after all.’\footnote{Note that this ‘passive’ idea (to be destroyed) is accomplished through the flexible transitivity system in Moloko\is{Transitivity!Clauses with zero transitivity}. The verb means ‘destroy’ but with the Theme as subject of the verb, the whole clause here expresses a passive idea (\chapref{chap:9}). }\\
I am going to the market.
I will go to the market.’\\
Come; I want us to pray together.
The young men left to bring back the tree; [but] they were not able to bring [it].’\\
If you want to grind, you take only one grain.’\\
It would please you to have the tree at your door, so that you could rest under it.’ \\
Each Sunday (the market of Dogba), some Molokos go to [work] their fields.’\\
because you can’t travel with them.’ (lit. it doesn’t take travel)\\
He/she planted many onions because his field was large.’\\
Your ducks keep dying.’ (lit. your duck, it dies it dies)
